title-group.article-title: Computational models and organizational psychology: Opportunities abound

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Justin M. Weinhardt is a PhD candidate in industrial/organizational psychology at Ohio University. His research interests include computational modeling, motivation, and decision making. He has published in Journal of Applied Psychology and Organizational Research Methods.

J. B. Vancouver is a Professor of Psychology at Ohio University, teaching in the PhD program in I/O Psychology. He received his degree in 1989 from Michigan State University (Department of Psychology). His research interests include motivation and decision making. Much of his work involves using complex protocols that generate time series data to assess dynamic computational models of a person interacting with the environment (usually the experimental protocol) based on a self-regulation perspective. To facilitate his work, he has developed an interdisciplinary group of electrical engineers, computer scientists, cognitive and other psychologists, mathematicians, and philosophers called HEIDi (Human–Environment Interaction Dynamics initiative). He is currently the PI of a 3-year NSF grant examining computational models of goal-driven decision making. His worked has been published in top psychology and management journals such as Psychological Bulletin, American Psychologist, Journal of Applied Psychology (JAP), Personnel Psychology, Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes (OBHDP), Journal of Management, Applied Psychology: International Review, Organizational Research Methods, and Human Resource Management Review. He currently serves on the editor boards of JAP, OBHDP, Academy of Management Review, and Journal of Business and Psychology.

abstract.p: Computational modeling has long been advocated as an important tool in the scientist’s tool shed. They are common in physical and biological sciences, but are very rare in organizational psychology. This paper describes the role computational models might play in informing theory and science in organizational psychology. After describing the major advantages of computational models, architectures, examples, and resources are described. This is followed by a comprehensive review of where computational models have been applied and where they might be profitably applied in each of the major domains of organizational psychology.

body.p: Humans and organizations have long been recognized as complex, nonlinear systems interacting dynamically. Consistent with this conceptualization, organizational scholars have advocated the use of sophisticated conceptual (e.g., Hulin, Henry, & Noon, 1990; Kammeyer-Mueller, Wanberg, Glomb, & Ahlburg, 2005; Mitchell & James, 2001; Vancouver, 2005), methodological (e.g., Beal & Weiss, 2003; Dalal & Hulin, 2008), and analytic strategies (Bliese & Ployhart, 2002; Chan, 2002; Curran & Bauer, 2011; Ployhart & Vandenberg, 2010; Schonfeld & Rindskopf, 2007). Certainly, one can argue that most organizational behavior theories are dynamic, in that they describe feedback loops and nonrecursive relationships (Katzell, 1994), or perhaps that they ought to be (Mitchell & James, 2001). However, it is also fair to argue that these dynamic elements are often described in off-handed ways that make the theories difficult to understand and test (Adner, Pólos, Ryall, & Sorenson, 2009; Harrison, Lin, Carroll, & Carley, 2007). Although, scholars’ capacity to understand the implications of theories about dynamics, both in terms of internal logic of the theories and predictions that follow from them, is limited (Hintzman, 1990; Johnson-Laird & Yang, 2008). To compensate for the limitation, many have argued for formal (e.g., mathematical) methods of theorizing (e.g., Adner et al., 2009; Simon, 1992). Unfortunately, most formal theories are static snapshots of dynamic phenomena with a single criterion (Luce, 1995). Yet, it is the dynamics that can be most difficult to understand (Cronin, Gonzalez, & Sterman, 2009; Kleinmuntz, 1990; Navarro & Arrieta, 2010; Sterman, 1989), leading many to advocate for computational modeling as the formal method to develop, represent, and assess dynamic theories (Davis, Eisenhardt, & Bingham, 2007; Harrison et al., 2007; Vancouver, Tamanini, & Yoder, 2010). In Table 1 we provide a preview of topics that will be covered throughout the current article.

body.p: Computational models are algorithmic descriptions of process details, typically operationalized as computer programs that are dynamic and can be simulated (Taber & Timpone, 1996). The goal of computational modeling is to create a representation of the system-in-context that approximates the underlying process of the phenomenon we as researchers are trying to understand (Myung, 2003). Perhaps more importantly, computational models can be simulated, allowing one to examine how the representation behaves over time and how the variables in the system and context change over time. Thus, the simulated computational model allows the theoretician to “think through” the implications of the theory as well as to “see” the predictions the theory makes (i.e., “crunch the numbers”). Perhaps equally important, the formal nature of the computational model allows others to witness the exact propositions of the theory. Therefore, there is much less room for ambiguity and much greater room for falsifiability (Edwards & Berry, 2010; Gray & Cooper, 2010; Meehl, 1978).

Yet, there are relatively few computational models in organizational psychology, which we believe is problematic for the reasons illustrated in our section on the advantages of computational modeling. One of the reasons for the lack of computational models in organizational science may be a lack of knowledge. In particular, computational modeling, like all theorizing, is typically cumulative and expansive. That is, models are often built to represent existing imprecise or less accurate theories (Busemeyer & Diederich, 2010). They are also often built using larger computational architectures. Thus, to add to our extent existing computational theories to organizational phenomena, organizational scholars need some familiarization with the nature, advantages, variations, and resources concerning existing computational approaches. These issues are covered first. Most importantly though, we believe that it would be useful to illustrate the types of phenomena computational models might help us understand. Toward that end, the bulk of this paper includes a review of the primary areas of interest to organizational psychologists, what computational models already exist in those areas, and what issues will likely benefit from computational models not yet developed.

sec.title: Computational models and their compensations
sec.p: To understand the advantage of computational models, we must describe their alternative—the informal theory. Informal theories, also called verbal theories (Sun, 2008) or natural language theories (Adner et al., 2009; Powers, 1991), have all the richness of language at their disposal. Unfortunately, they have all the ambiguity as well. In contrast, Adner et al. (2009) noted that formal models have three advantages over informal theories; specifically, formal models provide a more precise, transparent, and internally consistent approach to theorizing. For computational models in particular, the internal consistency arises from the need to get a working simulation where the system of interest exhibits the phenomenon the theory is intended to explain. Otherwise, one must rely on one’s mental simulations, which are notoriously defective (Johnson-Laird &Yang, 2008), particularly when considering dynamic processes (Cronin et al., 2009). Understanding dynamic processes can be much more difficult than an informal description implies, as captured in this quote by Hintzman (1990): “To have one’s hunches about how a simple combination of processes will behave repeatedly dashed by one’s own computer program is a humbling experience that no experimental psychologist should miss” (1990, p. 111).

We see no reason why organizational psychologists should not be exposed to this humbling experience. Indeed, the field is replete with theories of constructs linked together in strings of causal relationships (e.g., Locke & Latham, 2004). Each relationship might be logically and empirically defendable, perhaps backed with a meta-analysis, but which together does not describe a viable system. The requirement that one simulate a computational model forces the theoretician to determine if the description is viable (though not necessarily valid; i.e., a true representation of the system). Moreover, it often requires that the modeler “fill in” aspects of some verbal theory in order to get a viable representation (Busemeyer & Diederich, 2010). This process is a form of theory refinement that increases both internal consistency and precision in terms of theoretical description.

Besides theoretical precision, formal theories and particularly computational models enhance predictive precision as well (Adner et al., 2009). For computational models, this too is accomplished via simulations because they show what happens as constructs interact with one another over time, perhaps revealing emergent phenomena (Harrison et al., 2007; Hulin & Ilgen, 2000; Vancouver, Tamanini, et al., 2010; Vancouver, Weinhardt, & Schmidt, 2010). Several researchers have shown that understanding dynamics well enough to derive accurate predictions is often very difficult, and even well educated individuals are often wrong in their assessment of even relatively simple dynamic problems (Cronin et al., 2009; Sweeney & Sterman, 2007). Uncovering emergent dynamic phenomena, whether consistent or inconsistent with observations of the system of interest, is very difficult without the external aid provided by simulated computational models (Adner et al., 2009).

The final major advantage of formal theorizing is transparency (Adner et al., 2009). In particular, a quantitative description of the form of relationships leaves little room for ambiguity regarding what is meant by the constructs in a theory and how the constructs influence one another. Indeed, one issue computational models struggle with is internal validity. In computational modeling circles, internal validity refers to the degree to which a modeler has accurately represented an informal theory (Taber & Timpone, 1996). The problem is that because of the ambiguity in informal theories, modelers might not represent the theory accurately. To us, this illustrates the transparent value of formal theory and the lack of transparency often true of verbal theories. That is, if one claims that x model is not what some theoretician meant, then one should develop a model that does represent what the theoretician meant. That way, everyone can see for themselves what some theory describes and the models can both be subject to tests of internal and predictive consistency. After all, the name of the game is representing the system, not representing the theory.

The described advantages translate into more specific advantages, including theory building (Hulin & Ilgen, 2000), formally describing and testing parts of an existing present theory (Vancouver, Putka, & Scherbaum, 2005), resolving conflicting theoretical issues (Vancouver & Scherbaum, 2008), and resolving conflicting empirical findings (Vancouver, Tamanini, et al., 2010). Finally, a major benefit of computational models is that they can be a cost-effective and practical means to study a wide range of phenomena (Davis et al., 2007; Zickar & Slaughter, 2002). That is, they can allow one to explore phenomena or theoretical implications regarding systems for which it is difficult to get good data due to ethical or practical issues. They can also maximize the diagnostic value of data collection by making it clear what observations are needed to assess a theory against its predictions or its competitors (Vancouver, Tamanini, et al., 2010). To drive these advantages of computational models home, we provide two recent examples. We also present a simple example of a computational model so the concept is less abstract.

sec.title: Theory refinement and resolving empirical findings
sec.p: Vancouver, Tamanini, et al. (2010) is an example of how computational models can aid theory development and resolve conflicting empirical findings. Specifically, they observed that the empirical data surrounding proactive information seeking behavior among newcomers (i.e., proactive socialization) did not seem to conform to the theory used to explain the behavior. Using a computational model of the theory, they demonstrated that the theory could account for the existing empirical literature, but was not diagnostic of the theory. That is, they illustrated that the apparently inconsistent observations were a function of design and measurement decisions. Using the model they were able to show that the typical positive effect between information seeking and role clarity arises as a function aggregating seeking behavior and the timing in which the data is collected. Their simulation also showed that an individual enters an organization without knowledge and therefore engages in information-seeking behavior, but as knowledge increases, seeking behavior declines, thus revealing a negative relationship between knowledge and information-seeking behavior. Moreover, they demonstrated that an alternative theory, also computational modeled, could account for the existing data.

Vancouver, Tamanini, et al.’s (2010) primary models also revealed several important and surprising findings. For instance, they varied individual difference parameters, like the propensity to seek information, to reveal how the individual difference parameters influence newcomer socialization. For example, one set of simulations indicated that individuals with a high propensity to seek information would be likely to seek less information than a low-propensity individual once they have been in the organization for awhile. This is because these individuals seek and obtain information more quickly, resulting in a steeper decline in their information seeking due to a decline in a need for information. Finally, from these simulations, a number of hypotheses can be made about newcomer socialization and empirically tested in the field. For example, when do individuals with high intelligence compared to individuals with low or moderate levels of intelligence begin to decrease information-seeking behavior and how may this influence performance by those individuals controlling for intelligence?

sec.title: Theory integration and development
sec.p: For a very different issue, Vancouver, Weinhardt, and Schmidt (2010) highlighted the use of computational models in theory integration and development. Their model provides a formal, dynamic theory of multiple-goal pursuit with a deadline. The model integrates theories of goal-striving with theories of goal-choice, which are typically considered separately (Diefendorff & Lord, 2008; Klein, Austin, & Cooper, 2008). More specifically, the model integrated theories from decision making (e.g., subjective expected utility), economics (e.g., hyperbolic discounting), and motivation (e.g., self-regulation). Yet surprisingly, the model is conceptually parsimonious because it was able to represent these various theories using the same computational architecture.

Besides integrating existing theory, the model expanded upon those theories and provided an account for an unexplained empirical finding. Specifically, Schmidt and DeShon (2007) had shown that individuals working on competing goals with a single deadline tended to switch back and forth to the task with the largest goal discrepancy, but as the deadline approached individuals stayed with the task with the smallest discrepancy. Schmidt and DeShon could offer no theoretical explanation for this reversal effect. In Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al.’s (2010) computational model, they included a dynamic expectancy element that changed in response to discrepancies in the task and the individuals’ behavior. Previous theories that use the expectancy construct have always conceptualized it as a relatively static variable, changing mostly between persons but not across time. This dynamic representation of expectancy was able to account for the reversal effect found in the Schmidt and DeShon study.

sec.title: A simple example of a model
sec.p: As the discussion about verbal theories illustrates, talking about computational models is one thing; seeing them is another. Thus, to give the flavor of a computational model we provide a very simple example. This model is a possible account for a famous finding in behavioral economics, commonly referred to as the taxi driver study (Camerer, Babcock, Loewenstein, & Thaler, 1997). The taxi driver study tested the intertemporal substitution theory of labor and leisure (Lucas & Rapping, 1969), coincidentally a mathematical model of dynamic decision making. Much like expectancy theories in psychology, the intertemporal substitution theory predicts that individuals will work longer when their wages are higher. Most taxi drivers can determine how long they work each day and wage rates vary between days because it is easier to find fares on rainy days than on sunny days. In contrast to the theory, Camerer et al. found that taxi drivers spent more time working on low-wage days compared to high-wage days. The researchers attempted to explain the findings in terms of goals and the complex nonlinear utility curves associated with prospect theory (Tversky & Kahneman, 1992). However, it turns out a simple model of goal pursuit may be all that is necessary.

Specifically, Figure 1 displays a system dynamics model (Forrester, 1968) of the taxi driver. The model represents a postulation, consistent with Camerer et al.’s (1997) explanation, that taxi drivers often have a monetary goal for a day’s work (i.e., daily monetary goal) and they drive until they reach this goal. Specifically, the “comparator” is a simple subtraction equation (i.e., discrepancy = daily monetary goal – earned income) used to represent the comparison of the goal value, which is a constant in the model, with the income earned, which is a dynamic variable that changes as the driver works (i.e., drives taxi). Dynamic variables are said to have a memory in that they retain their value over time, but can be changed by flows into and out of the dynamic variable occurring at specified rates (Vancouver et al., 2005). In system dynamics, dynamic variables are called stocks because they behave like stocks in an inventory with processes affecting additions to (i.e., flows into) and subtractions from (i.e., flows out of) the stock (Forrester, 1968). To represent the memory feature mathematically, dynamic variables are represented as integral functions in system dynamic models because time is represented continuously (Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al., 2010). In this case, the rate of flow into the income earned is the wage rate for the day, a parameter in the model, thus:

The “drivetaxi” variable is the result of an equation that merely translates to 1 any positive output (i.e., discrepancy) from the comparator function (i.e., drivetaxi = 1, if discrepancy > 0; else, stop simulation). We ran two simulations of the model to represent 2 days with different wage rates. The results on earned income over time are shown in Figure 2. The results clearly show that it takes longer to reach the daily monetary goal when the wage rate is lower.

Now one might wonder why we would bother to represent the above argument computationally, given it seems so straightforward. One answer, of course, is that we wanted a simple example to illustrate the concept of a computational model. We trust we have done that. Another answer, though, is that the model shows that Camerer et al.’s (1997) findings can be explained without using the complex utility function of prospect theory. It may be a simple case of goal striving (Vancouver et al., 2005). The model confirms that such a simple theory could work (i.e., run and account for the finding).

To be clear, a model that works does not mean it is the explanation. Other theories/models might also produce the same effect. Computational models can provide another means for disconfirming a theory, but they should not be considered a proof of theory (Popper, 1969). As the field matures, it would be ideal to see models tested competitively against one another. This is a common practice in cognitive psychology, which should be adopted in organizational psychology. A more thorough discussion of evaluating computational models in organizational psychology can be found in Vancouver and Weinhardt (in press). Now that we have discussed some of the advantages of computational models and an example of a computational model, we will move into a discussion of levels of analysis in computational models.

sec.title: Levels of analysis in computational models
sec.p: Level of analysis is a familiar topic to organizational researchers (Klein & Kozlowski, 2000) and is a very important topic in computational modeling. Sun, Coward, and Zenzen (2005) described four levels of cognitive modeling, including interagent (e.g., social, cultural, or organizational), agent (e.g., psychological), intra-agent (e.g., componential or modular), and substrates (e.g., physiological/biological). Although these levels are roughly isomorphic with disciplines (Sun, 2008), some disciplines clearly bridge two or more. The level of analysis issue is well known in organizational behavior because it often bridges the interagent and agent level (called meso- or cross-level research), and, as we argue presently, agent and intra-agent levels. Interestingly, behavioral economists have even become interested in the intersections between the substrate (i.e., neurological) and higher levels (Loewenstein, Rick, & Cohen, 2008).

Modelers are often interested in how processes at one level interact to account for processes or behaviors at a different level (Vancouver, 2005). This is the concept of emergent properties (Schöner, 2008). This is particularly relevant for a form of modeling called agent-based modeling (Bonabeau, 2002) and a related form, called cellular automata (Lomi & Larsen, 1996). Both involve representing relatively simple entities (i.e., agents) that interact with each other to account for higher order properties. The agents represented generally range from individuals to organizations. For instance, Bonabeau (2002) describes a model of crowd flows during panic evacuation conditions (e.g., conditions that lead to stampedes, injuries, and deaths) and another about drivers on highway systems. Architects and civil engineers when designing stadiums and traffic systems can use these models. For example, the crowd flow model shows that a column placed in front of and slightly asymmetric to an exit substantially reduces injuries to individuals seeking a rapid escape from a room compared to a room without such a column. This counterintuitive finding would be difficult to predict or study systematically without a model. Another example is the work by Lomi and Larsen (1996) where the agents are organizations and the issue is changes in population densities as a function of legitimation (i.e., degree of conformity of new venture with established rules and expectations) and competition (i.e., joint dependence on limited resources).

As the above examples illustrate, the unit of analysis that is the “agent” might vary depending on the problem examined. In much of the modeling in organizational theory (Lomi & Larsen, 2001), organizations or industries are the agent-level unit whereas markets, cultures, or industries are the higher unit of analysis. Recently, Vancouver , Weinhardt, et al. (2010) argued that the simple input, comparator, and output functions of a control system represent an agent and that much human behavior can be accounted for using one or more of these simple agents (see also, Vancouver, 2008). The taxi driver example presented above is an example of this idea (note that the input function is not shown). This type of modeling is more consistent with Sun et al.’s (2005) third, componential level (i.e., what they called the “intra-agent” level) because the behavior of the higher order system is explained as a function of the components within the system. Indeed, agent is a term that conveys the notion that some entity has its own desire(s). In Vancouver’s (2008) theory, models of humans with multiple desires can be presented in terms of multiple control agents (i.e., with multiple desires). Of course, because humans have these desires (i.e., they have several desiring control systems nested within them) and humans are nested within organizations or other social units, one can choose any of these units to be the agent level where the choice depends on the phenomenon one wishes to explain. In fact, when one reads about agents or systems in a paper, one has to pay attention to the level of analysis described as these words are largely level independent (i.e., one researcher’s system is another’s subsystem).

One of our contentions is that at least some organizational scholars should be modeling the intra-agent (e.g., componential or modular) level within humans to account for (i.e., explain) human behavior as it plays out in work settings. These models can then be used to represent human agents in more complex ways than is typically done in agent-based modeling (not always necessary) or to link with substrate models (e.g., when examining health and stress issues). However, they are likely to provide substantial insights on their own. Fortunately, organizational scholars do not need to start from scratch. There are several broad computational approaches, called architectures, that exist in the cognitive literature. These architectures can provide the building blocks for creating computational models of the kind of phenomena organizational psychologists might find interesting. Due to space limitations, we cannot provide an exhaustive list or descriptions of the architectures, but we provide references for the major modeling architectures.

sec.title: Kinds of computational architectures
sec.p: Computational models have long been popular in cognitive psychology (e.g., Newell & Simon, 1963), forming one corner of the broad discipline called cognitive science (Newell, 1990). There are generally two kinds of computational models: declarative and numerical. Declarative models, which in cognitive psychology are also called “production” or “symbolic,” are logic-based algorithms (e.g., if-then statements) that use representations of knowledge within the human as the basis for the models (Bringsjord, 2008). The original cognitive computational model, called the general problem solver (GPS; Newell & Simon, 1963), was a declarative model. Current declarative models include Soar (Newell, 1990), and perhaps most familiar to this audience, ACT (adaptive control of thought; Anderson, 1983). Sometimes these types of models are called first-generation or good old-fashioned AI (artificial intelligence) models (Boden, 2008), though the goals of artificial intelligence (i.e., creating models that act like humans, though preferably without the imperfections, as in expert systems) only partially overlap the goals of cognitive science (i.e., creating models that represent the processes that humans use that determine their behavior). Declarative models have been most successful at modeling cognitive performance like problem-solving and learning behavior. For example, Johnson-Laird and Yang (2008) describe various models of mental simulations and how they are used to diagnose breakdowns or the truth value of declarative statements.

Declarative models are closely linked to nonmathematical formal logic theories (Adner et al., 2009). In contrast, numerical (also called quantitative) models more closely resemble mathematical models. In psychology, or more generally cognitive science, there are a large number of these types of theories. For example, readers may be familiar with neural net models, or connectionist models. Connectionist models are typically used to address cognitive phenomena (McClelland & Rumelhart, 1981; McClelland, Rumelhart, & The Parallel Distributed Processing [PDP] Research Group, 1986; Rumelhart, McClelland, & The PDP Research Group, 1986), but they have also been used by organizational psychologists to address motivation (Lord, Hanges, & Godfrey, 2003). Another class of computational models is based on control theory or cybernetic models (Rosenblueth, Wiener, & Bigelow, 1943), like perceptual control theory (PCT; Powers, 1973). Control theory models have mostly focused on perceptual and motor systems (Jagacinski & Flach, 2003), but they have also been applied to decision processes (e.g., Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al., 2010). The taxi driver model described above is a control theory model. Other computational modeling approaches include systems dynamics models (e.g., Forrester, 1968; Sastry, 1997), Bayesian models (Griffiths, Kemp, Tenenbaum, 2008), evolution-inspired models (e.g., Bruderer & Singh, 1996; Rivkin, 2001), agent-based models (Bonabeau, 2002), and dynamical system (Schöner, 2008), which are different from systems dynamic models. All of these latter types are more popular in macro-OB (organizational behavior) areas (Davis et al., 2007; Lomi & Larsen, 2001).

More recent hybrid models, which include both declarative and quantitative elements, are beginning to emerge. These include ACT-R (adaptive control of thought-rational) (Anderson et al., 2004) and CLARION (connectionist learning with adaptive rule induction online) (Sun, 2006). In reality, the distinction between the two approaches is not very large given that mathematics, which is used by the numerical modelers, is merely a form of logic, which is used by the declarative modelers. sec.title: Models in organizational psychology: Opportunities abound
sec.p: Above we noted that organizational psychology is inherently interested in dynamic phenomena. To drive that message home, we systematically review organizational psychology topics that might benefit from dynamic computational models and propose which computational architectures may be most useful as a basis for that modeling. We group topics in sections similar to what one might see in an industrial/organizational textbook. Within each topic we cite examples of computational models where they exist and specific issues or theories that seem ready for or most in need of computational support.

sec.title: Training and development
sec.p: Learning and development are dynamic processes where computational modeling seems a natural. Actually, computational models have commonly been used to understanding learning, and some of these have been applied in training contexts. For example, many textbooks mention two concepts from one of the major computational architectures (i.e., declarative and procedural knowledge in ACT; Anderson, 1983) without mentioning the computational heft that girds that theory. Many also mention computer-based training technology, while failing to mention how computational modeling is used in some of that training. Specifically, Anderson and colleagues (see Koedinger, Anderson, Hadley, & Mark, 1997) have developed and tested intelligence tutoring systems that “ran production rule models in parallel with a student and attempted to interpret the student behavior in terms of these rules” (Sun, 2008, p. 13). This interpretation is used to diagnose progress and to tailor the training protocol accordingly. Of course, specific models and tutoring systems need to be made for specific training material. These materials have been developed, mostly in mathematics, and are being used in thousands of schools across the United States with great success (http://www.carnegielearning.com/). That said we know of none developed for work settings.1 The first step is to create computational models of the learning processes involved. Even if one does not use this to create an intelligent tutor, the results might be used to understand why individuals have trouble learning certain elements and what might address those troubles.

Interestingly, another place computational models have come into play is in the area of organizational learning (Carley & Hill, 2001; March, 1991; Senge, 1990). More of a macro-OB issue, it is interesting to observe that the organizational learning movement somewhat arose from the research on human limitations regarding handling dynamic phenomena that we cited earlier (e.g., Kleinmuntz, 1990; Sterman, 1989). Moreover, training in computational modeling has been used in an attempt to approve organizational managers’ ability to think dynamically (R. E. Wood, personal communication, April 16, 2006). Again, though, it is not clear how well one can think dynamically without the external supports mathematics and modeling provide. Moreover, because science is a social enterprise, thinking dynamically is only half the game. Communicating one’s thinking is the other half. Computational models are excellent vehicles for communicating one’s theory explicitly and in a reproducible way (Harrison et al., 2007).

Finally, a side topic of training and development, socialization, has also been the focus of computational models (Harrison & Carroll, 2001; Vancouver, Tamanini, et al., 2010). The Harrison and Carroll model includes attraction-selection-attrition (ASA; Schneider, 1987) processes as well as socialization processes. The Vancouver et al. model was described above. It focuses primarily on proactive (i.e., newcomer-motivated) socialization, but that paper also has a submodel with socialization directed by organizational representatives.

The above examples are not meant to convey that training and development is an area that is already saturated with computational models. This is nowhere near the case. Not only are the models mentioned ripe for expansion (e.g., where ideas from verbal theories can be integrated), but also many issues remain to be modeling at all. Learning has been an early focus of cognitive computational models because it is clearly a complex dynamic phenomenon with many subprocesses. Most of the cognitive work has been on childhood learning issues; leaving much to be done regarding adult learning and development. However, this is one area where there are mature architectures that intrepid organizational psychologists might use as a starting point for their own programs of research.

sec.title: Job and task analysis
sec.p: Just as learning and development researchers should be interested in modeling the processes by which one learns how to perform tasks and jobs, organizational and micro-OB researchers should be interested in the processes individuals use while performing jobs and tasks. For most organizational psychologists, job analyses focus on individual differences that one might select for or train on, rather than the dynamics involved in performing a job or the tasks within it. In contrast, human factors and cognitive psychologists have focused a great deal of attention on the dynamics of performance, often turning to computational models to support that work. For example, much of the first-generation AI (and thus computational) models were focused on problem-solving tasks, like the Tower of Hanoi (Simon, 1992), or more obvious work tasks like designing algorithms (Newell, 1990) or editing books (Eberts, 1997). This work, coupled with cognitive task analysis, is often used to increase efficiency and to provide materials for training (Howell, 2003). Likewise, human factors researchers have created computational models of the processes involved in perceptual-motor tasks, like backing segmented semitrucks into docking bays (Jagacinski & Flach, 2003). The military, in particular, have been strong advocates of computational modeling individuals and higher level entities (i.e., units and commands) for purposes of understanding the enemy, populating training simulations, and facilitating performance across the levels of analysis (Pew & Mavor, 1998). Indeed, funding from military sources is often contingent on the research team’s ability to computationally model the theories being developed (R. P. DeShon, April 28, 2011, personal communication).

A more meso-OB issue that would likely benefit from computational modeling relates to the processes involved in negotiating jobs (Ilgen & Hollenbeck, 1991). That is, jobs and roles are now seen as fluid rather than static or fixed (Borman, Klimoski, & Ilgen, 2003). Specifying the processes involved would likely be beneficial not only in terms of theoretical clarity, but also in terms of their ability to make specific predictions of changes over time.

sec.title: Work behavior
sec.p: Work behavior relates to criteria used for assessing selection systems and other interventions. One of the thornier issues regarding criteria is its possible dynamic quality (Steele-Johnson, Osburn, & Pieper, 2000). Dynamic criteria refer to changes in the predictive validity of different predictors (e.g., Ackerman, 1988) or of different criteria over time. This problem lends itself to computational modeling, and at least one model has been created regarding the first kind of dynamic criteria (Scherbaum, Vancouver, & Finlinson, 2003), but in that case the model was used more as a basis for assessing a statistical procedure for detecting dynamic criteria than as an attempt to represent the processes that might bring about the effects. In addition, Keil and Cortina (2001) used catastrophe-chaos models heuristically as a framework for how validity degrades overtime. However, they did not use catastrophe-chaos models to analyze the data nor did they present a computational model based on catastrophe-chaos models. Such work still needs to be done.

Another topic of central interest among those interested in performance criteria is its breadth and multidimensionality (Motowidlo, 2003). That is, performance has traditionally been conceptualized as performances on specific duties specified by the job, but now there is a great deal of interest in extrarole or contextual performance. It seems a model similar to WORKER, which deals with the interaction between dimensions of withdrawal (Hanisch, Hulin, & Seitz, 1996), might be constructed for performance. Of course, to model processes related to performance, one must conceptualize performance not as static (i.e., an individual performs at some level across time), but rather as dynamic, where it ebbs and flows across minutes, hours, days, weeks, or years. On this point there are a number of theories, mostly in the area of motivation (Kanfer, 2009), that might usefully be converted into computational models.

sec.title: Motivation
sec.p: Like learning, motivation seems a topic where computational modeling would be prominent given the dynamic nature of the phenomenon (Atkinson & Birch, 1970; Dalal & Hulin, 2008). However, unlike learning, cognitive psychology has tended to ignore motivational processes (Boden, 2008). Fortunately, this is where organizational psychologists have begun to step up. In particular, Lord et al. (2003) developed a computational model of Vroom’s (1964) valence, instrumentality, expectancy (VIE) theory using an approach inspired by connectionism. The basic issue their model addressed was the criticism that because the processes described by VIE are thought to require a great deal of cognitive (i.e., attentional) resources, it is not a very useful theory for describing anything but the most important decisions. Lord et al.’s model showed that simple, parallel processes could easily process the information needed for optimizing choices across differing goal priorities. So far, there has been no follow-up to this model, but it seems to us that it could be the beginning of an interesting line of research. In particular, it seems that one (or a team) might integrate the spreading activation concepts found in computational architectures, like ACT-R, and motivational theories, like Atkinson and Birch’s achievement motivation theory, with the decision dynamics represented in Busemeyer and Townsend’s (1993) decision field theory (DFT) computational model of decision making.

Another line of motivational research by organizational psychologists has focused on goal-setting and self-regulation processes. Specifically, Vancouver et al. (2005) demonstrated a control theory inspired model to account for the goal-level (i.e., goal-difficulty) effect. This model has been followed up with a model of goal-discrepancy production (Scherbaum & Vancouver, 2010), a test of a model of self-regulation of perceptions against a model of self-regulation of behavior (Vancouver & Scherbaum, 2008), and a model of multiple-goal pursuit under time constraints (Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al., 2010). These models are based specifically on Vancouver’s (2008) control theory inspired architecture of self-regulatory processes within humans. This architecture includes acting, learning, thinking, and emotional components, although not all these components are reflected in published models. Moreover, the approach could likely be relatively easily tied to other architectures found in cognitive psychology given the underlying control (cybernetic) theory found in many of these architectures (Boden, 2008).

Besides what has been said, many topics and theories seem ready for computational modeling within the motivation domain. For example, another prominent and dynamically oriented theory within motivation that would likely benefit from computational modeling is social cognitive theory (SCT; Bandura, 1986). SCT is a comprehensive and highly praised motivation theory that is relevant to many organization issues (Latham & Pinder, 2005), but it is a verbal theory. Certainly, a central question is whether SCT would reduce to control theory once one attempts to represent the processes described (Scherbaum & Vancouver, 2010; Vancouver, 2005). Given Vancouver et al.’s (2005) model of goal level, this reduction appears to be the case with goal-setting theory (Locke & Latham, 1990), though many processes (and findings) within that theory have not been modeled. Finally, we want to encourage researchers to operationalize processes related to static motivation theories. This is what Lord et al. (2003) did with VIE. Moreover, Vancouver, Weinhardt, et al.’s (2010) model of multiple-goal pursuit includes components from VIE as well as control theory and Steel and König’s (2006) temporal motivation theory—another dynamic work motivation theory.

sec.title: Performance management
sec.p: Performance management is another area where motivational processes are likely important, but might be combined with equations representing environmental systems (i.e., performance management systems). An example of this was presented by Schwab and Olson (2000). They looked at the effects of different pay-for-performance systems (e.g., bonus pay; merit-based pay) on the relationship between pay increment and performance both across virtual individuals and across time. This model did not represent processes within individuals, though. An example of a theory in performance management that is ripe for computational modeling would be Kluger and DeNisi’s (1996) feedback intervention theory, which is based on control theory. We could also envision the possibility that a sophisticated model of manager performance might reveal the source of variance in performance across constituents (e.g., subordinates, superiors, peers) that could be used to account for these differences, while reducing them to a relatively small set of parameters. For example, the model might include (a) a job knowledge component, perhaps using ACT-R architectural features, (b) a problem-solving and task assignment component, perhaps using SOAR’s architecture, and (c) a social status component that determines interactions styles as a function of relative status (i.e., a parameter). Such a model might provide specific clues regarding how to improve the manager’s performance for the next or subsequent evaluations. Such a model/application may be far-off; but could represent a specific, difficult goal for a young academic’s program of research.

sec.title: Personnel decisions, assessment, and individual differences
sec.p: Personnel selection and assessment is an area that has seen the most computational modeling work by organizational psychologists. For example, Sackett and colleagues (Sackett & Roth 1991, 1996; Sackett & Wilk, 1994) ran Monte Carlo simulations of selection systems with varying rules (e.g., banding strategies) and conditions (e.g., selection ratios) to assess the effects on adverse impact (i.e., a specific level of disproportional hires between individuals of certain groups) and other variables (e.g., quality of hires). In general, they found that there was little an organization could do within the constraints of the law that could reduce adverse impact if the predictors had substantial mean group differences, as is the case with intelligence tests. On a related vein, Martell, Lane, and Emrich (1996) simulated the effects of multiple promotions on the glass ceiling for women. They found that the differences in the probability of promotions for men and women—slight for any one promotion decision—translate into a remarkably large effect across the normal number of promotions required to obtain the higher echelons of an organization.

For something completely different, Zickar (2000) examined the impact of faking on personality tests used in selection contexts. Numerous studies have found that the predictive validity of personality assessments do not seem to suffer much, even when test takers are instructed to fake “good” (i.e., answer items in a way they think would make them look good to the organization). Zickar’s simulation showed that when some are faking and some are responding honestly, validity coefficients are not substantially affected, but that a disproportionate number of fakers received top scores (and are thus likely hired even though they do not possess high levels of the desired personality trait).

These models are interesting and provide useful data, but they are not psychological. Instead, we describe three areas where computational models of psychological processes are primed for construction and likely to provide payoffs for organizational psychologists.

Our first example involves intelligence testing. As noted before, intelligence tests are not only a source of adverse impact, but also a robust, reasonable predictor of job performance (Drasgow, 2003). Given these two conditions, organizational psychologists should be very interested in the processes involved in, used by, and that can possibly change intelligence (Nisbett, 2009; Weinhardt & Vancouver, 2012). One way to begin this process might be to computationally represent either information processing or neuropsychological models of intelligence (Drasgow, 2003). Once developed, tasks might be developed that obtained a more fine-grained assessment of intelligence or that can show how to compensate for relative deficiencies.

Our second example involves personality and the psychological models of person–environment interactions that can be the basis for computational models of personality, context, and behavior (Read & Monroe, 2008). These are likely to begin with Mischel and Shoda’s (1995, 1998) CAPS (cognitive-affective personality systems) framework or the more narrowly specified (but still fairly grand) KAPA (knowledge-and-appraisal personality architecture) approach outlined by Cervone (2004). Read and Miller’s (2002) neural network model of approach and avoid goal systems can serve as a “model” of a computational model of processes that give rise to personality. For organizational psychologists, the questions such models might address relate to the role of personality dimensions on performance and other criteria, the contexts under which the dimensions will likely matter most, and potentially more valid measures of measurement.

The third example involves assessment. In particular, computational models are being developed by cognitive psychologists (e.g., Busemeyer & Stout, 2002; Wallsten, Pleskac, & Lejuez, 2005; Yechiam & Busemeyer, 2008) that reveal that a single performance score on standard assessments—used for clinical purposes in these cases—can be the result of subprocesses with separate individual difference parameters. Moreover, knowledge of the individual differences parameter values can be recovered using the computational models fitted to data from individual respondents (e.g., Yechiam, Busemeyer, Stout, & Bechara, 2005). In particular, these models use data from the time series of data available from dynamic tasks, often operationalized on computers, to fit the parameter values (see model fitting description below). Clearly, organizational psychologists might be able to tap into this approach to develop new selection measures and to diagnose problem performance among other applications.

sec.title: Attitudes, emotions, and related behavior
sec.p: Organizational textbooks typically discuss job satisfaction and organizational commitment as attitudes of relevance to micro-OB because of their relation to withdrawal behaviors (e.g., turnover). One of the first computational models by organizational psychologists focused on withdrawal behaviors (Hanisch et al., 1996). Like some of the other organizational-relevant models discussed above (e.g., Martell et al., 1996), this was a model of the effects of individual processes, not of the processes within individuals that account for behavior. It assessed the effects of different types of the relationships (e.g., independent, progressive, spillover, etc.) among different withdrawal behaviors (e.g., absenteeism, turnover, etc.). The model has been used to assess the effects of various organizational policies (e.g., incentives for early retirement) on attitudes and behaviors in the dynamic populations within organizations over time (Hanisch, 2000). These simulations show, among other things, that traditional research designs will have a difficult time uncovering the nature of processes responsible for withdrawal behaviors given the dynamics and the complexities involved.

Cognitive and social psychology computational models also exist that are related to attitudes and emotions (Boden, 2008; Read & Monroe, 2008). Undeniably, attitude change has long been a topic of mathematical and computational inquiry (e.g., Abelson & Carroll, 1965). These models are often conceptualized around concepts of cognitive consistency, which are construed as constraint satisfaction models in computational modeling circles (Read & Monroe, 2008; Thomas & McClelland, 2008). Moreover, the importance of conceptualizing attitude as a dynamic variable (i.e., a stock variable) was an important finding in the development of mathematical models of attitudes (J. E. Hunter, personal communication, October 14, 1984).

The confluence of both these past modeling approaches would likely be very beneficial to organizational psychology. Most theories of attitudes in organizations are based on implicitly dynamic theories of comparison processes (Locke, 1976) and these are often coupled with slightly more explicit dynamic theories of withdrawal processes (e.g., Steel, 2002). Computational models would be very useful at (a) clarifying similarities and differences among competing models, (b) determining the implications of the models over time, and (c) determining what research designs will be required to assess the theories. For instance, what is particularly striking about Hulin and Judge’s (2003) review of the attitudes literature was (a) the ubiquitous appearance of the control theoretic comparison concept, (b) the lack of rigorous association between organizational concepts of attitude and social concepts of attitude, (c) the lack of consensus regarding which theory describes the process best, and (d) the lack of ideas regarding how to assess the various theories. We suspect computational modeling would be fairly easy to do given the first observation and very useful in addressing the later three problems.

The above stated condition of the attitudes literature has been long-standing. More recent advancements in the field are also likely to benefit from computational modeling. For example, person–environment fit models, with their predictions of nonlinear effects, have become a major new perspective in the area (Hulin & Judge, 2003). Unfortunately, they are notoriously static in description, despite being clearly dynamic in operation. In fact, Kristof-Brown and Guay (2011) suggest a more dynamic focus, by asking questions like how are fit perceptions formed and changed. We might also want to consider how and when individuals (or organizations) change the environment to increase (or decrease) fit as well as how or when they react to the lack of it (i.e., withdrawal).

The other major new development in organizational attitude research is Weiss and Cropanzano’s (1996) affective events theory. This is an explicitly dynamic theory that was coupled with close attention to research design issues commensurate with its dynamic nature. Nonetheless, we suspect that the nonlinearity and interactions between levels of analysis described in the theory might be difficult to fully appreciate without the support of computational models.

sec.title: Stress and health behavior
sec.p: Stress and health behavior is another topic with a long history of comparison-based linear and nonlinear person–environment fit models (Edwards, 1992). It is also an area that is not modeled by cognitive psychologists for the most part, but there are exceptions relating to mental health issues (Busemeyer & Stout, 2002). However, some health researchers are beginning to create models of health behavior (Riley et al., 2011). Perhaps not surprisingly, these models are based on control theory, which is also the heuristic inspiration for many stress theories in organizational and OB (Edwards, 1992). Edward’s theory in particular, which is an amalgamation of older theories, is an example of a verbal theory (with graphics) that might benefit from computational rendering. Initially, these models are not likely to be all that different from models of attitudes, but eventually and depending on the phenomenon of interest, researchers in this area are likely to want to link to more physiological modeling efforts, whereas attitude researchers are more likely to want to link to meso- and macro-level models.

sec.title: Teams
sec.p: Teams and groups are a meso-OB topic with social psychological roots. As such, models by social psychologists (e.g., Latané, 2000; Stasser, 2000), organizational psychologists (Coovert & Dorsey, 2000; Kuljanin & DeShon, 2011), and management researchers (Loch, Huberman, & Ülkü, 2001) have been created. Stasser’s (2000) model focuses on collective information processing and team decision making. It models the exchange of information among team members leading to a team decision. Latané also models social impact using a cellular automata approach, which is used in physics, biology, and mathematics more generally. Coovert and Dorsey used a Petri net (Desel & Silva, 1998) approach, which came out of chemistry, to model individual and team performance (i.e., number of tasks and time to complete) as a function of roles in the group. Kuljanin and DeShon’s model uses “human dynamics” (Barabási, 2005), which is borrowed from physics, to model coordinated action among teammates. Interestingly, the most psychological model is provided by Loch et al. (2001), where subjective utilities are calculated by group member and used to determine the allocation of efforts, which in turn affects relative status and work productivity of the group. In regard to teams there are a number of important issues that need to be addressed, but we believe two are particularly important and can greatly benefit from computational modeling. The first issue, is the type of team that should be formed given a particular situation. For example when dealing with complex multifaceted problems should teams be structured with members in a complimentary fashion? Another issue that we believe will greatly benefit from modeling is understanding how the structure of teams influence group performance and perceptions of group and individual performance. Social psychological research on social loafing and group dynamics can greatly influence the development of these models. As these examples make clear, models of team phenomenon can focus on different levels of analysis, different issues, and use approaches from many different disciplines.

sec.title: Leadership, negotiation, and organizational-level issues
sec.p: Somewhat like the teams literature, the computational models in this area are more the topic of meso- and macro-OB domains. As such, they are described in other works advocating computational models in management (e.g., Davis et al., 2007; Harrison et al., 2007). That said there are models that use more cognitive approaches, particularly in areas of negotiation and “game playing” (Sun, 2008). Interestingly, CLARION, which is a hybrid of cognitive model of symbolic and connectionist architectures, has also been used to understand behavior in organizations (though this particular instantiation might be better classified as a model of teams). Specifically, Sun and Naveh (2004) found that when compared to human data, the results of this cognitive model outperformed four agent-based models (Carley, Prietula, & Lin, 1998), leading Sun (2008) to extol the advantage of cognitively based social simulations. We suspect that this advantage may not always be the case, but that there are a number of meso- and macro-level phenomena for which a more complex representation of the individual players might lead to better predictions. These complex representations might be instantiated as agents in the agent-based models, integrating the two approaches. Certainly, this is perhaps the central motivation for the organizational psychologist to pursue computational models of the interagent processes; that is, they can be used as part of higher level simulations of person-in-context models. We believe agent based-models will be most fruitful in the area of organizational-level issues. This is because an agent can represent an organization and then these agents can be simulated over time to reveal emergent behavior. For example agent-based models will be particularly useful for examining competition among a number of competing organizations for market share. Finally, leadership research is beginning to conduct longitudinal research studying leadership over time across many different contexts (Day & Sin, 2011), therefore computational models will be a great resource to help refine and test theories. The area of research is replete with many conflicting theories and theories that discuss the role of the environment as influencing leadership. Therefore, computational models will be extremely useful in getting a better understanding of the nature of leadership.

In sum, we reviewed the major domains of organizational psychology, pointing out places where computational models have been used and where they are likely to be beneficial in the near or distant future.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The goal of the paper was to encourage organizational psychologists to develop their theories into more rigorous computational models for the purpose of better theory, better prediction, better research, and better communication. We described a myriad of dynamic organizational psychology phenomena that might benefit from a computational approach. Truth is it is difficult to think of research topics that are not dynamic, and therefore likely would not benefit from a computational model or two. Indeed, we opened a recent issue of the Journal of Applied Psychology (January, 2012) to test this assertion. What we found was enlightening.

The first article (Colquitt, LePine, Picclo, Zapata, & Rich, 2012) was about the justice–performance relation. They depict and test a sequential causal model beginning with justice perceptions and ending with job performance. We are not critiquing this model or method, but it is clear to us that dynamics can and should be incorporated into theories of justice and performance. Colquitt et al. (2012) described an uncertainty reduction process within the theory they were testing. Uncertainty reduction was the central process modeled in the Vancouver, Tamanini, et al. (2010) paper on proactive socialization described above. Recall that that paper highlighted the limitations of the research strategies employed given the dynamics involved. Seems the same problems might be at least possible when considering justice processes.

The next article (Schultze, Pfeiffer, & Schulz-Hardt, 2012) was about escalation of commitment. Escalation of commitment is inherently about the role of previous decisions on subsequent decisions. A primary observation in this literature is that one increase resources when feedback indicates things are not going well (Vancouver, 2012). One way to think about this is that one’s car is slowing down because one has begun going up a hill. The response is to increase gas to the engine (i.e., escalate resources). This can be modeled simply; indeed, engineers have models of just this type of context in order to create cruise control mechanisms. Of course, there are other interesting issues surrounding human escalation of commitment in applied settings. Perhaps it is time to explore computational models that might account for these issues.

The third article (Johnson, Ilies, & Boles, 2012) was about affect. It related to issues discussed earlier in the section on affect. The fourth article (Sturman, Shao, & Katz, 2012) was about turnover, also discussed above. The fifth article (Bagozzi, Bergami, Marzocchi, & Morandin, 2012) was about the development of a customer–organization relationship. Any developmental topic is inherently dynamic. The next three articles were about culture and organizational phenomena. The role of culture was not discussed earlier, but acculturation is a process and the role of culture in group, performance, and performance management, all topics discussed above, could likely benefit if plugged into a dynamic model of processes to these topics. In fact, all the remaining articles in the issue related to dynamic issues described before. This does not mean that these articles are uninformative regarding theory—that depends on the research question—but that organizational psychology provides a rich landscape for developing dynamic computational models.

It has been our experience that most newcomers to the field of organizational psychology struggle to find their focus. It seems every topic has been broached; every question researched. Yet, repeating what has been done in the past is no longer of interest in the present. One has to find something new. We are arguing here that if you are looking for a way to make a mark in the field; a way to make a unique contribution; a way to strengthen the science, there may be a computational model in your future.

We should distinguish computational models of learning work tasks from artificial intelligence programs designed to represent the very knowledgeable in some domain (i.e., expert systems). These programs are closely related to computational models, but they are not specifically intended to further understanding of organizational behavior, but rather to provide a support mechanism for working individuals (or groups).
